courses.name: Principles of Finance
courses.description: Financing business, consumer, and government activity; stocks, bonds, real estate, and financial markets; risk; insurance; inflation; cash and income management; capital accumulation and appreciation.
courses.prerequisites: Students admitted to COB upper level degree program cannot enroll

courses.name: Survey of Business Finance
courses.description: An overview of the global financial system, financial markets, financial institutions, and principles of financial management.
courses.prerequisites: Students admitted to COB upper level degree program cannot enroll

courses.name: Corporate Finance
courses.description: Financial decision-making in a corporate environment. Time value of money, capital budgeting, cost of capital, working capital management and financial instruments issued by the firm.
courses.prerequisites: Completed 45 semester hours; STAT 2500 (or STAT 2200 and STAT 1200 or STAT 1300 or STAT 1400); ACCTCY 2027 or ACCTCY 2037 or ACCTCY 2137H; ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024; ECONOM 1015 or Econom 1051 or 1051H

courses.name: Personal Risk Management and Insurance
courses.description: Teaches the importance of risk in personal endeavors and the intelligent handling of such risk. Life, health, auto, homeowner and liability risks are treated.

courses.name: Financial Management
courses.description: Theory and techniques of financial management, study of firm valuation, dividend policy, capital budgeting and capital asset pricing.

courses.name: Investments
courses.description: Security valuation and analysis, formulation of personal and professional investment programs.

courses.name: Investments - Honors
courses.description: Security valuation and analysis, formulation of personal and professional investment programs.

courses.name: Financial Intermediaries and Markets
courses.description: Functions of intermediaries in the aggregation and allocation of funds, creation and transfer of assets, and distribution of risks. Regulation of financial institutions; financial institutions as instruments of public policy.

courses.name: Financial Management Policy
courses.description: Application of the concepts and tools of finance to cases in working capital management, capital budgeting analysis and capital structure decisions.

courses.name: Security Analysis
courses.description: Classifies and analyzes securities, markets, industries. Formulation of investment policy for institutions, aggressive personal investors.

courses.name: Management of Financial Institutions
courses.description: Operating principles of major financial intermediaries, including commercial banking, savings, insuring, lending and investing institutions. Analysis of cases; study of current problems.  Some sections of the course may be graded on A-F or S/U graded basis only.

courses.name: Problems in Finance
courses.description: Independent study, reports on selected topics.  Some sections of this course may be offered A-F only or S/U only.

courses.name: Topics in Finance
courses.description: Selected topics in finance, insurance or real estate. Offered on an experimental basis.  Some sections of this course may be offered A-F only or S/U only.

courses.name: Portfolio Management
courses.description: Development and application of the principles of modern portfolio theory to financial assets. Analysis of the concepts of diversification, portfolio construction, portfolio revision, and use of types of financial assets in effective portfolio management.

courses.name: Financial Modeling and Databases
courses.description: Financial modeling and using online databases to retrieve data, data analysis, spreadsheet design, excel VBA programming, interpreting results. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Financial Futures and Options
courses.description: A basic overview of financial futures and options markets. Topics include: theoretical pricing of financial futures contracts and stock options, institutional aspects of these markets, hedging, and speculative strategies.

courses.name: Financial Ethics and Professional Standards
courses.description: The course comprises an intensive study of the CFA Institute Code of Ethics and Standards of Professional Conduct and Global Investment Performance Standards. It also includes a review of corporate governance issues.

courses.name: Principles of Real Estate
courses.description: Principle factors influencing land use, practices in real estate business.

courses.name: Real Estate Appraisal
courses.description: Procedures for valuing industrial, commercial, residential realty by market, income, replacement cost approaches. Case method, field investigations.

courses.name: Real Estate Finance and Investment
courses.description: Financing of residential, commercial, and industrial real estate and real estate development. Instruments, institutions, and markets; role of government agencies; investment qualities of real estate.

courses.name: Real Estate Portfolio Analysis and REITs
courses.description: Management of real estate portfolios and analysis of real estate investment trusts including financial statement analysis, cash flows, and valuation techniques.

courses.name: Investment Strategy of Warren Buffett
courses.description: Survey and application of the investment philosophy and valuation methods of Warren Buffett.

courses.name: Introduction to Risk Management and Insurance
courses.description: Basic principles of risk management and insurance focusing on operational risks faced by organizations. Covers terminology, sources, dimensions, characteristics, measurement, and assessment of risk along with design and implementation of techniques to mitigate and control risk.

courses.name: Principles of Commercial Property and Liability Insurance
courses.description: The objective of this course is to examine the principles and key elements of commercial property and liability insurance. The primary emphasis will be on the property and liability loss exposures faced by organizations and the corresponding types of insurance for covering those loss exposures. This course qualifies students who make a "B" or better to receive credit for CPCU 552 Commercial Liability Risk Management and Insurance.
courses.prerequisites: FINANC 2000 or FINANC 3000 or FINANC 4630, or permission of the instructor

courses.name: Enterprise Risk Management
courses.description: This course addresses the principles, concepts, key elements and applications of Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) to businesses and other organizations. The principal objective of this course is to prepare students to understand the principles of ERM and to be able to integrate sound risk management principles into their work.

courses.name: Topics in International Finance
courses.description: Available during study abroad session. Emphasis is on international corporate governance, foreign exchange risk management, international capital markets, balance of payments, international monetary system, and exchange rate determination. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: International Finance
courses.description: Application of domestic corporate finance to the international arena. Emphasis on international capital budgeting, working capital management, foreign exchange risk management, international capital markets, balance of payments, international monetary system, and exchange rate determination.

courses.name: Investment Fund Management
courses.description: Analysis and management of securities and markets by participation in the management of a student-run portfolio of publicly traded stocks and bonds. May be repeated once for credit for a total of six credits.
courses.prerequisites: FINANC 3000, FINANC 4120 or FINANC 4620, instructor's consent required each enrollment

courses.name: Chartered Financial Analyst Exam Review Course
courses.description: (cross-leveled with FINANC 7830). A review of the content and format of the chartered financial analyst (CFA) examination. Students need to be registered for the CFA exam to enroll in the class.

courses.name: Angel Capital Education Program
courses.description: (cross-leveled with FINANC 7840). In depth understanding of investing in start up enterprises, including structuring investment deals, doing due diligence, and monitoring of prior investments. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Professional Finance Internship
courses.description: Provides students experience with financial activities in business organizations (or, occasionally, in a governmental or not-for-profit setting). Students are required to prepare and execute a plan of study approved by the instructor and the complete written assignments detailed in the plan.
courses.prerequisites: FINANC 3000, College of Business students with a finance concentration or international business students with a finance emphasis, and instructor's consent

courses.name: Financial Management
courses.description: Theory and techniques of financial management, study of firm valuation, dividend policy, capital budgeting and capital asset pricing.

courses.name: Investments
courses.description: Security valuation and analysis, formulation of personal and professional investment programs.

courses.name: Special Topics in Finance
courses.description: Selected topics in Finance, insurance, or real estate.  Offered on an experimental basis.

courses.name: Microeconomics for Business
courses.description: Examination of how the behavior or consumers and the business decisions of firms affect supply, demand, and the resulting prices of goods and services in the market.

courses.name: Economics for Managers
courses.description: Applies the concepts and tools of economics to management issues and problems.

courses.name: Managerial Finance I
courses.description: Introduction to financial management including the time value of money capital budgeting techniques, risk measurement, and the valuation of financial securities.

courses.name: Managerial Finance II
courses.description: Continuation of the study of financial management with focus on the risk-return tradeoff, capital structure, corporate layout polices, long-term financing, elementary options pricing, and mergers and acquisitions.

courses.name: Managerial Finance
courses.description: Analyzes financial information relative to acquisition, management of assets; costs of alternative financial contracts; effect of mix of outstanding securities on entity's cost of capital; interaction between funding/investment decisions.

courses.name: Investment Strategy of Warren Buffett
courses.description: Survey and application of the investment philosophy and valuation methods of Warren Buffett.

courses.name: Investment Fund Management
courses.description: (cross-leveled with FINANC 4820). Analysis and management of securities and markets by participation in the management of a student-run portfolio of publicly traded stocks and bonds.  May be repeated 1 time for credit.

courses.name: Chartered Financial Analyst Exam Review Course
courses.description: (cross-leveled with FINANC 4830). A review of the content and format of the chartered financial analyst (CFA) examination. Students need to be registered for the CFA exam to enroll in the class.

courses.name: Angel Capital Education Program
courses.description: (cross-leveled with FINANC 4840). In depth understanding of investing in start up enterprises, including structuring investment deals, doing due diligence, and monitoring of prior investments. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Topics in Finance
courses.description: Selected topics in finance, insurance or real estate. Offered on experimental basis.

courses.name: Multicultural and Global Finance Study Abroad
courses.description: International topical issues in finance including cultural difference, corporate governance, differential approaches to regulation across countries, and cross-risk. Includes a study abroad component with on-site visits to businesses and other organizations. May be repeated as venues change.

courses.name: International Financial Markets
courses.description: International capital, foreign exchange, money markets, and financial institutions including exchange rates, instruments and securities, and multinational risk exposure. May include a study-abroad component with on-site visits to businesses and other organizations. May be repeated as venues change. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Security Markets and Investments
courses.description: Valuation of securities including stocks, bonds, options and futures; risk-return analysis of financial assets.

courses.name: Problems in Finance
courses.description: For independent investigation and analysis, graduate students select topics suggested by the foregoing undergraduate courses.

courses.name: Master's Thesis Research
courses.description: Advanced research leading to thesis.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Financial Databases and Analysis
courses.description: Financial modeling and using online databases to retrieve data, data analysis, spreadsheet design, excel VBA programming, interpreting results. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Financial Modeling
courses.description: Financial modeling using Excel spreadsheet design and VBA programming. Includes alternative computational methods, simulation and the use of information retrieved from financial databases. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Financial Markets
courses.description: Operation and structure of money markets and capital markets, including markets for stocks, bonds and derivatives securities. Study of the securities that trade in those markets including characteristics, valuation and diversification.

courses.name: Investment Policy and Portfolio Management
courses.description: Study of investment policies and the effects of risk and diversification on investment management including measurement of risk, identification of investment policy, and construction and maintenance of investment portfolios.

courses.name: Derivative Financial Securities
courses.description: Comprehensive overview of derivative securities including financial futures and options, swaps, and financial engineering. Major topics: institutional aspects of these markets, advanced pricing models, pricing relationships among derivative securities, and risk shifting.

courses.name: Financial Statement Analysis I
courses.description: An introduction to financial statement analysis with emphasis on interpretation and understanding of the balance sheet income statement, and statement of cash flows.

courses.name: Financial Statement Analysis II
courses.description: Analysis of company financial statements and related accounting information with emphasis on investors' decisions to invest in the company.

courses.name: Equity Securities Analysis
courses.description: Theory and application of models and methods for valuing common stocks.

courses.name: Fixed-Income Securities Analysis
courses.description: Markets for fixed-income securities and theory and application of models for valuing bonds and other fixed-income securities.

courses.name: Investment Banking
courses.description: Topics in investment banking including types of offerings and securities, analysis of comparable companies and transactions, valuation methods, and hedge funds and private equity. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Financial Management
courses.description: Examination of the modern theory of finance. Capital budgeting capital structure, dividend theory and valuation.

courses.name: Working Capital Management
courses.description: Financial planning and short-term financial management; integration of quantitative techniques, microeconomics, and financial decisions; analysis of decisions about profit planning, financial forecasting, accounts receivable, cash management, and financial short-term assets.

courses.name: Capital Budgeting
courses.description: An investigation of long-term financial decisions. Topics include capital budgeting, leasing, long-term financing. Extensive use of cases.

courses.name: Financing Multinational Business
courses.description: Study of foreign exchange markets, currency derivatives, global capital budgeting, and international financial decision strategy. Some sections of this course may be offered on an A-F or S/U basis only.

courses.name: Ethics and Standards of Financial Practice
courses.description: Study of financial ethics with particular focus on standards of practice for investment performance standards.  Recommended for students planning to take the CFA exam.

courses.name: Mergers and Acquisitions
courses.description: Analysis of merger and acquisition transactions. Includes methods of financing, valuation and deal structure, hostile takeovers and restructuring.

courses.name: Management of Financial Institutions
courses.description: Study and analysis of policies, goals, practices and organizational changes in the management of financial institutions and intermediaries.

courses.name: Real Estate Investment I
courses.description: Analysis of real estate as an investment including forecasting net operating income and cap rates, risk analysis estimation of return on investment, and syndication.

courses.name: Real Estate Investment II
courses.description: A continuation of FINANC 8520. Advanced risk analysis, syndication, and renovation and disposition of investment property including case analyses. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Real Estate Portfolio Analysis
courses.description: Portfolio analysis applied to real estate investment including diversification, portfolio theory, and management of real estate portfolios including real estate investment trusts (REITs).

courses.name: Real Estate Finance
courses.description: Instruments and methods of financing real estate including fixed and variable rate mortgages, the mortgage loan underwriting process, financing investment property, and alternative financing methods. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Real Estate Valuation I
courses.description: Valuation and appraisal methods for real estate. Includes cost, comparable sales, and income capitalization approaches. Credit may not be earned for both FINANC 7510 and FINANC 8550. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Real Estate Valuation II
courses.description: A continuation of FINANC 8550. Focus is on advanced methods and the use of case analyses. Credit may not be earned for both FINANC 7510 and FINANC 8552. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Real Estate Securities Analysis
courses.description: Analysis of real estate securities including in-depth financial statement analysis and valuation of real estate investment trusts (REITs) and real estate operating companies (REOCs).

courses.name: Real Estate Development
courses.description: Developing real estate properties. Topics include organizational forms, land development, construction, and environmental issues. Includes issues specific to residential, office, industrial, and retail properties. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Investment Strategy of Warren Buffett
courses.description: This course is designed to familiarize students with the investment philosophy of Warren Buffett. Buffett's criteria for evaluating potential acquisitions and investments will be analyzed in detail.

courses.name: Corporate Risk Management
courses.description: Principles of identifying, analyzing, assessing, and managing operational risks faced by large organizations. Sources, dimensions, and qualities of risk as well as development and implementation of methods to avoid, control, or transfer risk.
courses.hours: 1-3Prerequisites or Corequisites: FINANC 7420Recommended: Undergraduate Business degree with major/emphasis/minor in Finance, Accounting or Economics

courses.name: Corporate Insurance and Alternative Financing Mechanisms
courses.description: Basis and techniques for insuring hazard and operational risks encountered by large organizations. Analysis of insurance policies, determination of optimal limits and retentions, and assessment of alternative risk financing methods.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Finance
courses.description: Selected topics in finance.

courses.name: Research in Finance
courses.description: Thesis research for Ph.D. degree. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Seminar in Corporate Finance
courses.description: Advanced theory, investigation of current research in financial management.

courses.name: Topics Seminar in Finance
courses.description: Reading and critical evaluation of selected current finance literature and research.  Departmental consent. May be repeated. Graded on S/U basis only.  students only

courses.name: Research in Corporate Finance
courses.description: Advanced topics in corporate finance.

courses.name: Financial Economics
courses.description: Utility analysis, efficient frontier mathematics, asset pricing and related topics.

courses.name: Seminar in Investment Analysis
courses.description: Develops integrated theory and analytic techniques for evaluating investment potential of financial instruments. Emphasizes corporate securities. Selected cases and readings.
